name: Malaga
fun_fact: Fun fact: Malaga is the birthplace of Pablo Picasso AND Antonio Banderas, both of whom remained deeply connected to the city's food culture - Banderas still frequents El Pimpi restaurant when visiting, while Picasso once said the smell of espetos on the beach was the scent of home.

hero_dishes.name: Espetos de Sardinas
hero_dishes.description: Sardine skewers slowly roasted over open fires on the beach - smoky, salty, and quintessentially Malaga
hero_dishes.origin_story: This 19th-century tradition began with local fishermen cooking their catch on the shore. The sardines are threaded on cane skewers and cooked in boats filled with sand over olive wood fires, creating an unforgettable smoky flavor
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Hermanos Alba (in El Palo seaside district - one of Malaga's most celebrated seafood spots), beach chiringuitos along the coast

hero_dishes.name: Gazpachuelo
hero_dishes.description: A creamy fisherman's soup made with mayonnaise, fish broth, potatoes, and white fish or prawns - rich and comforting
hero_dishes.origin_story: This typical Malaga fisherman's dish was once humble family food, but it's now a celebrated part of local cuisine. The mayonnaise emulsified into the broth creates an unexpectedly luxurious texture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Pimpi (Antonio Banderas's favorite, stays true to traditional recipe), traditional malague침o restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Porra Antequerana
hero_dishes.description: A thick cold soup similar to gazpacho and salmorejo, made with tomatoes and dried bread, topped with hard-boiled eggs, tuna, and serrano ham
hero_dishes.origin_story: While gazpacho is famous throughout Spain, porra antequerana is Malaga's own version - thicker and served with more substantial toppings, perfect for hot Andalusian summers
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Tapeo de Cervantes (popular tapas bar in central Malaga), Casa Lola

hero_dishes.name: Berenjenas con Miel de Ca침a
hero_dishes.description: Fried aubergine (eggplant) served with sugar cane honey - a sweet and savory combination
hero_dishes.origin_story: This tapa dates back to the Moorish period in Andalusia when sweet and savory combinations were common. The contrast between crispy fried eggplant and sweet molasses is addictive
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mes칩n Mariano (best berenjenas fritas in the city), traditional Andalusian restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Malaga Sweet Wine
signature_drinks.description: Sweet fortified wine made from Moscatel grapes - amber-colored, aromatic, and intensely sweet
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as a dessert wine or aperitif, often paired with local pastries or cheese. Malaga wine has been produced here since Phoenician times

signature_drinks.name: Tinto de Verano
signature_drinks.description: Red wine mixed with lemon soda and ice - refreshing and lower alcohol than sangria
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The drink of choice for locals in summer (tourists get sangria). It's lighter, more refreshing, and what Malague침os actually drink on hot days
